Rules and recommendations

If a pregnant woman has met with a Covid positive person or she displays symptoms of the coronavirus, the general rules apply to her (Illness and regulations). Inform your doctor, who will best advise you on the next steps to take. Do not visit your general practitioner or gynecologist without prior telephone consultation. 

For pregnant women who haven't been in contact with anyone positive and don't display any symptoms, nothing changes. Despite this, follow all hygienic regulations. 

Pregnant women who have tested positive for the coronavirus can give birth in a maternal hospital. It is necessary to inform the doctors and follow all hygienic measures. It is also important to pay extra attention to the hygienic rules to prevent the infection of hospital staff.

If a pregnant woman is in quarantine or isolation and she needs to visit the maternity hospital (to give birth or for a necessary check up) she should arrive in her own vehicle. You can also call 112 (emergency services) and have an ambulance take her to the hospital if no one else is available. Inform the medics about quarantine or isolation in advance and upon arrival. Please also wear a face mask or a respirator. 

In general, hospital visits are not allowed.

The exception to this rule is presence during childbirth, if the following conditions are met. The person visiting is the father of the child (usually the husband or partner) or a person living in the same household as the mother. Other people can't be present during the birth. Before entering the maternity hospital, the visitors temperature will be measured (has to be lower than 37,5°C) and they cant show any symptoms of the coronavirus (Illness and regulations > Symptoms) they have to wear at least a surgical face mask the whole time (not a fabric one). The birth must take place in an individual room or birthing area and visitors can't come into contact with any of the other future mothers.

Care for the mother and the baby during and after birth will not go through any significant changes. It is necessary to follow all hygienic measures. Medical facilities are facing a challenging time, but maternity care and care for newborns is secured. There is nothing to be afraid of. Please inform your doctors about anything related to the coronavirus spread so they can take preventative measures and ensure the safety of the medical workers, pregnant women, their visitors and other patients in the hospital. The birth of your baby will be a joyful occasion and a safe one as well.

questions_answers.question: Can my husband be present during the birth?
Can I breastfeed if I have the coronavirus?
questions_answers.value: Yes, transmission via breast milk hasn't been proven. The only risk is the close proximity of the mother and baby (and the possible infection from respiratory droplets). Please disinfect your hands before and wear a mask when breastfeeding your baby or pump your breastmilk and a negative person can feed your child.

questions_answers.question: Can I give birth in a maternity hospital if I have the coronavirus?
questions_answers.value: Yes, but inform your doctors before your arrival.

questions_answers.question: Can the virus be transmitted from a pregnant mother to the baby she is carrying?
questions_answers.value: No such case has been recorded, even in worse cases of the disease. The presence of the virus was not found in amniotic fluid or breastmilk.

questions_answers.question: Does a woman infected with the coronavirus have to give birth by caesarean section?
questions_answers.value: No. It depends on the health conditions of the mother, if infected giving birth might be more difficult, but the final decision is always up to the doctors under specific conditions. If the mother has a lighter course of the disease, the birth should go ahead in a similar manner as planned.

questions_answers.question: Is the treatment for pregnant coronavirus patients different?
questions_answers.value: Pregnant women should be under regular medical care. If they are infected with the coronavirus during their pregnancy they could be preventatively hospitalized to be under more direct medical surveillance. Id depends on the course of the illness, generally, there shouldn't be any difference.

questions_answers.question: Can pregnant women receive antiviral medication?
How can I prevent getting infected?
questions_answers.value: Wear your face mask, wash your hands regularly, avoid crowded places, use single use tissues and take care of your health- both physical and mental.
